text: Images of an upscale suburban community. Boats on the water. A quiet street. A picket gate. EXT. BACK YARD OF A BEAUTIFUL HOME - LARCHMONT, NY — MORN

It's a gorgeous spring day, and we move in on an impeccab laid out garden. Straight rows of flowers in full bloom, manicured bushes, and a trellis with climbing vines. BECCA CORBETT, attractive, 30's, walks into frame draggin heavy bag of potting soil. She pulls the soil bag over to section of the garden where she had been digging, and cut the bag open. Becca dumps the soil onto the ground where she is plantin flowers. Behind her, we see part of her fine house and across the street, a shimmering stretch of water. Becca is on her knees now mixing potting soil with earth. She starts to plant a straight line of young plants as a border to her flower-bed. She picks up the hose from beside the free-standing garag Near her we notice an empty doghouse A little later, Becca stands with a hose, watering the garden. She admires her day's work.
Becca? Becca turns to see her neighbor PEG, middle-aged, peeking from behind the gate leading to the next property. She co into the garden. Becca is a little uncomfortable, but alw polite.
Oh...Hey Peg.
It looks so nice back here.
Well, I’m just, you know, trying to get things back into shape.
Listen, I don’t know if you and Howie are free tonight, but we’re having a few people over for dinner.
Oh, that’s very sweet of you.
I know it’s really short notice.
Actually, we have plans.
(beat) Oh. Oh, well.
But, uh, another time though. I haven't talked to Pete in ages.
Well you haven’t missed much. He’s still the same S.0.B. he always was. Peg chuckles. Becca looks down to see that Peg has steppe on a plant recently put in the ground.
Oh God. I’m so sorry. (steps off the plant)
It’s okay.
I am so sorry.
No, it’s fine.
These stupid feet.
Well, have a great dinner, Peg. This is her gentle cue to leave, and Peg gets the hint. S backs out of the yard politely.
We'll do it next time.
Absolutely. But they both know this is probably a lie.
Say hi to Howie for me.

I sure will. Becca closes the gate after Peg. As soon as she's gone, Becca moves over to tend to the crushed plant. She assesses the damage, and sighs, peeved INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN —- EARLY EVENING Becca stands at her sink, rinsing vegetables in a colande Across the way, she can see right into her neighbor's liv room, where Peg, PETE and their guests are chatting. Peg’s in the midst of a very animated story that has ever laughing hysterically. Becca watches for a moment, then turns off the water in the sink, dries her hands, and tur the blinds so no one can see inside. Howie, home from work, comes in and grabs a beer.
Mmmm. Smells good in there.
If Peg asks, we went out tonight.
Where'd we go?
We saw the Stoppard play.
Really?
Uh-huh.
Did we enjoy it?
Very much. Becca is at the stove now melting some butter in a pan.
She asked us to dinner again.
She's just being nice.
You're more than welcome to go over there.
And abandon your risotto? (wraps arms around her)
Careful, Howie. The pan’s hot. She pushes him off gently, and continues stirring the pot She’s all business tonight. Howie watches for a moment, then takes a bite of some of food being cooked.
(gently scolding) Hey...
Hey... (heads out) I’m gonna hop in the shower.

Uh-huh. About twenty minutes. INT. BECCA'S LIVING ROOM —- NIGHT A beautiful room. Becca sits on the couch reading. It's late. The house is quiet. We hear only a ticking clock. Then the phone rings, startling Becca. She doesn't move get it. She just stares at it, afraid to answer it. Finally she reaches over, and picks it up...
Hello? Becca listens. The news is not good. She’s confused.
What time is it?
Becca is pulling on her jacket when Howie comes downstair sleepy, in gym shorts and a t-shirt.
What’s going on?
Becca and her sister IZZY, early 30's, are walking down t steps and back to the car. Becca is pissed.
You have nothing to say?
(beat - confused) Thank you? This is not what Becca meant.
You were in a bar-fight.
It wasn't a bar-fight.
You were in a bar. Fighting.
It wasn’t a fight. Some drunk girl was screaming in my face, so I hit her and that was the end of it.
Well who was she?
I don’t know.
People don’t scream at you for no reason.
Sure they do, you should get out more.
God Izzy, it’s so...Jerry Springer.
What’s that supposed to mean? You think I’m trashy?
You can’t keep doing this. You’re not a kid anymore.
I didn’t know there was a cutoff date.
Well there is. For acting like a jackass, there’s a cutoff date... Becca unlocks her car as they approach - BLOOP-BLOOP.
I wanna stop worrying about you.
Hey, don't worry about me. She was the one on the floor. Becca and Izzy in the car.
Can I stay with you tonight?

One light turns on in a downstairs room.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY — A MOMENT LATER Becca sneaks out of her bedroom. She hears voices, and th distinct sound of a little boy laughing. She takes a moment, then steels herself and heads downstairs silently LIVING ROOM — CONTINUOUS Becca finds Howie, seated with the lights off, watching a video of Danny on his phone. He doesn’t notice her presen HOWIE (on video) Now, Danny, I wanna tell you a secret, ‘kay? When you go back down, give Mom a big kiss, okay? Ready?... One, two, three. ...Oh, that was high! Whoo! Howie smiles as he watches the video. He is smiling. HOWIE (on video) Danny, look at me when you come back. BECCA (on video) He’s getting used to it. HOWIE (on video) Do you want any cake? DANNY (on video) Yeah! HOWIE (on video) Oh, do we have cake today? BECCA (on video) Yeah, we do. DANNY (on video) Yeah. HOWIE (on video) Oh, my gosh. And you really want some? This is too hard for Becca. She backs away as the video continues, and sneaks back up the stairs, unnoticed.

A hand reaches into frame and draws a straight line in bl ink. The hand draws a parallel black line and then connec the two with an oddly shaped circular end. We pull back to reveal the hand is drawing a network of intersecting tubes and portal openings. The artist shades a section. INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN - THE NEXT DAY — MORNING Becca is putting some finishing touches on a creme brulee that she has just prepared in her kitchen. Her eyes narro in concentration as she carefully cauterizes the top of i into a brown hard shell. Izzy stands nearby in her bathrobe, waiting expectantly. Howie enters the kitchen with his gym bag.
Well, if it isn’t Ma Barker.
I’m sure that would be very funny if I knew who that was.
Rick and I are gonna play squash. (kisses Becca goodbye) I have my cell if you need me.
Squash. You go play squash, Howie.
You don’t even know what squash is.
I don’t care what squash is Izzy's cell phone rings. She checks the called I.D., and smiles while answering the phone.
(into phone) Hello? (heads out of the room) Yeah! Yeah. (laughs) I thought she was gonna kill me!
Izzy paces around the room while chatting on her phone.
(into the phone) Yeah, I know. I think Auggie must have told her. Izzy sees Becca enter the room holding up the créme brule
(into the phone) Hey, I gotta go. Izzy hang up the phone and excitedly takes the creme brul from Becca.
Mmm. Thank you Becca. Izzy takes a seat by the window, and starts tapping the caramel with the spoon.
Oo, I like the way it cracks.
Of course you do. Becca watches her eat for a couple moments. Then...
So you did know that woman.
(throws her head back) Oh my god! Why are you listening to my phone conversations?
Are you sleeping with that girl's boyfriend. Izzy eats, really wanting to change the subject.
It’s been over between them. They’re just living together because of the rent.
Then why did she accost you?  10.
Because she's a lunatic! (beat) And Auggie told her I was pregnant. Becca lets out a disapproving chuckle. But Izzy isn’t joking. Slowly...Becca realizes.
You are not.
You’re gonna love him. He's a really great guy. He’s a musician!
That's terrific.
He works, Becca. He gets work as a musician.
How long have you known?
A few weeks.
Did you tell Mom? Izzy nods sheepishly.
Oh, come on. You told Mom before me?
I had to.
Why didn’t you tell me?
Why do you think? This just sits there for a couple beats.
I’m sorry, Becca. I know the timing really sucks.  11.
Hey, what can ya do? Becca has been disarmed. How to proceed? Luckily, she’s a really good liar...
I’m just glad you finally told me. They hug. Becca is obviously still processing it.

Howie and his best friend, RICK, athletic, 30's, are in t midst of an intense game of squash. It's all grunts and thwacks and squeaking sneakers. Howie loses the point. INT. LOCKER ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Sweaty and spent, the men enter chatting. Their banter is easy and mostly good-natured.
Debbie’s been driving me crazy with these kitchen renovations. The counter-top negotiations alone...
I told you not to marry an agent. They open their lockers and get changed over the followin
She still hasn't called, you know.
(beat - guilt) No, I know.
I don’t mean to be a pest about it, but... I just know Becca would love to hear from her.
I know. I tell her, Howie. I do. But she’s still...I don’t know freaked out, I guess.
It’s been eight months.  12.
I know. I'll talk to her.
Thank you. (changing) Hey, how are the kids?
They’re good. Emily's doing ballet. Robby is in tee-ball.
Wow. Tee-ball. Howie tries to look interested, but Rick sees through it.
(tries to sound off-hand) Have you guys talked at all about having another?
(beat) No. (beat) It's a little soon. Rick nods. They go back to changing.
Becca and Howie talk quietly as they walk into the meetin room.
Just be open-minded. That’s all I’m asking.

I’m here, aren’t I? Couples mill about drinking coffee, waiting for the meeti to begin. Becca and Howie steel themselves as another cou approaches. GABBY is attractive. KEVIN seems tired. They both make Becca uncomfortable.
Hey.  13.
How's it going?
Good.
Yeah, good. Hanging in there. Howie looks to Becca, who looks a little ill at ease.
You sure?
Yeah. Yeah, um, we just...found out that Becca’s sister is pregnant. So.
(a warning) Howie.
What?
That can be hard, I remember when my cousin got pregnant--
Yeah, it's not really a big deal. Becca wants to end this conversation. She’s miffed Howie even brought it up.
Okay. If you wanna talk about it though, you know the group’s right here.
(chuckles ) Yeah, I don't think so. "Hey everybody, fresh meat."
Becca, be nice.  14.
(to Kevin) Doesn't she remind of you of Lydia? (back to Howie and Becca) There was this woman in the group a couple years ago--
It was four. Four years ago.
Well it doesn’t really matter when she was here, my point is that she reminds me of Lydia. She really wasn’t into the support group model at first.
Becca is suddenly confused. Did she just mishear her?
(confused) How long have you been in Group?
It'll be eight years in June. Becca is stunned, and can barely hide it. Eight years.
Oh, I didn’t... I didn’t realize it was that long.
Yeah, we’re the veterans. You know for us, it’s a good way to touch base. Everyone’s on a different schedule...

Of course. Becca is staring at Kevin. His misery is still palpable. And this terrifies her. INT. MEETING HALL — LATER THAT NIGHT The meeting is in full swing. A grieving father, SAM, is speaking to the group in a very heartfelt manner. His wif (ANA) holds his hand throughout.  15.
She, uh, she visits me sometimes. In dreams. And she tells me it’s okay. And she’s with God. He checks in with his wife. Then continues.

And we have good days. Then you think that if you have enough good days it might actually get better. But then... Several of the other parents nod with recognition. Becca, however, actually looks annoyed. She looks to Howie and rolls her eyes a little.
It was her anniversary last week.
A year last Tuesday.
And it just starts all over again. We just have to remind each other that it was just part of God’s plan. And we can’t know why. Only God can know why.
God had to take her. He needed another angel.
He needed another angel.
(beat) Why didn’t he just make one? Silence. They all turn to Becca, confused.

Another angel. I mean, he’s God after all. Why didn’t he just make another angel? She is met with stunned silence - a mix of confusion and offense. Even Howie is taken aback by her outburst. Gabby notices Kevin smirking a little.  16.
Just putting it out there... But no one responds. Becca leaves over to Howie and whispers...
I'd like to go. (to the group) I think we’re gonna go. (to Howie) Is that alright? Howie stands, stunned. He and Becca make an awkward exit.
Excuse us.
Becca and Howie look through the menus, mid-conversation.
They're talking, it’s their time, and you have to respect that.
Come on.
I mean, you sit there for weeks and you don’t say a word.
I’m sorry. I can’t stand the god- freaks. You know that.
But they're not all like that. Kevin and Gabby aren't.
No. Kevin and Gabby are professional wallowers. Did you hear what they said? Eight years, Howie. Eight. If that’s what you want to become, then...
Look, if you wanna take a break--  17.
No, not a break, I'm done.
I know the Izzy stuff got under your skin--
Please don't do that. One semester of Psychology fifteen years ago and suddenly you can analyze--
Well Jesus, Becca--
(a little too firmly) I just don't like the group. I gave it a try, and it's not for me.
This is final. Howie knows he can’t win this argument.
Okay. It’s not for you.

Thank you. (back to the menu...then) Do you mind if we not eat here? Nothing's really jumping out at me. He lets out a breath - perfect - and closes the menu. INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN — THE NEXT DAY Becca is alone in the kitchen. It’s the middle of the day and the house is deadly quiet. She’s been alone with her thoughts for awhile. She stares at the paintings on the fridge. She takes them in - a tree, a robot, a shark attacking a woman. They all have the distinctive scrawl o child, and the name Danny written across the bottom. Becca looks closely for a moment, and then removes the Magnets one by one, taking the paintings off the fridge, simply and without emotion.

Becca cleans out the kitchen cabinets. Kids’ cereals, jui boxes, mac & cheese, all tossed in a garbage bag.  18. INT. DANNY'S ROOM — DAY The room looks essentially the same as it did when Danny alive. Becca is at his dresser pulling clothes out of the drawers and tossing them into a laundry basket. She doesn pause over the clothes or give them much consideration. She's just doing the laundry.

Becca loads Danny's clothes into the washing machine. The water is running. She carefully fills a cup with soap pow and pours it over the laundry. She stops for a moment to watch the agitator grind away at the clothes. Then she closes the lid. INT. BECCA’S LAUNDRY ROOM — DAY Becca, holding the laundry basket, is standing, staring a the dryer. BUZZZZZZZ and the dryer cycle ends. She opens the dryer door and starts to unload. EXT. CITY STREET — YONKERS — DAY Becca drives through a less nice neighborhood.

Becca's car pulls into the driveway of a rundown house on rundown block. She gets out of the car, and lifts a large garbage bag from the trunk. She seems to be energized and better spirits. She walks up the driveway, and is suddenly startled by TA big dog barking on the other side of the fence that leads back. Becca stiffens, her good mood gone. The dog is loud and happy. AUGGIE, a scruffy African American guy in his 30’s comes across the yard with a heaping bowl of dog food.
Taz! Stop! Come here and eat! Come on! Taz goes running to the bowl of food, and Auggie approach Becca at the fence. She’s confused. Who is this guy?  She’s not She fixes 19.
Sorry. He’s not really dangerous. (to Taz) Hey, eat. (to Becca) Just kinda dumb.
No, I know. He’s my dog.
Oh, you're Becca! Of course! I should've recognized you. I’m Auggie. sure how to take this. What has Izzy told him? a loose strand of her hair.
Oh. Hi, Auggie.
Hi. Auggie and Becca shakes hands. The front door opens to re NAT, Becca’s mom, plump and in her sixties.
Oh my god, why didn't you tell me you were coming over? I would've picked up the house. (indicates) That’s Auggie.
Yeah, we met. Is Izzy here?
(her eyes narrow) Oh yeah, she's here. (does not approve) She got fired from the Applebee's. Becca follows her mother into the house.
Becca, chipper again, is unpacking the piles of Danny's clothes onto the table. Izzy sits watching, not exactly s what to say. She’s uneasy.  20.
I was planning to bring it all down to Goodwill, but now I'm glad I didn't. Look at all these shirts, and the sweaters. Nat buzzes around making them coffee.
I don't know, Bec. They're in baby clothes for so long, it'd be awhile before he could even fit into that stuff.
It comes up very quickly. You'll see. You’re gonna be happy I saved them. Auggie crosses through the kitchen with bagpipes.
(whispers) Is he living here?
He has to. His girlfriend kicked him out.
Ex-girlfriend.
She knew what I meant. Becca holds up a little shirt.
Did you see this one?
Cute. But what if it's a girl?
Then I'll give them to someone else. You're gonna thank me. A couple years worth of clothes here. Think of the money you'll save.
It's not about the money.
Well it should be. You need to start thinking about that. Especially if the dad's a musician. It costs a lot to raise a child.

(finally) It'd be weird, Becca. If it's a boy. To see him running around in Danny's clothes. (beat) I would feel weird about it. The air is sucked out of the room. Becca looks down at th clothes, suddenly feeling a little stupid. Nat doesn't mo Her eyes look from one daughter to the other.
Yeah, I’m sorry. Of course it'd be weird. I don't know what I was--
It was a nice offer.
You’re gonna get a lot of clothes anyway - Christmas, Birthdays. You won’t have to worry about that. She's re-bagging the clothes. Nat tries to lighten the mo
It's probably a girl anyway. I'ma little psychic about these things. Remember I said Sheila was having a girl? And Karen? I think there's a girl in there.
I hope there is. That's what I want. I mean, either way, so long as it's healthy obviously, but I hope it's a girl.
Me too. She looks to Izzy and tries to smile supportively.  22.
You want some coffee cake, honey? I got some coffee cake in here.
I'm gonna take off. I promised Howie that I'd pick up some dinner. (re: cake) Mmm looks good though. Becca lifts the bag, awkwardly. Nat and Izzy exchange loo After Becca’s gone...
(to Izzy) Here. Eat some cake.

Becca gets out of her car, grabs the garbage bag of cloth from her trunk, and makes her way to the Goodwill drop-bo Once there, she considers what she's about to do for just moment, and then lifts the bag into the drop box. She tur on her heel and heads back to the car, without looking ba INT. BECCA'S CAR — A MOMENT LATER Becca pulls up to a stoplight, and she takes a deep breat determined to hold it together. A school bus pulls up beside her car, and Becca glances o at it. Sitting in one of the window-seats is a teenage bo facing front. Becca stares at him curiously. And then the grip on her steering wheel tightens. The boy turns his head slightly and for just a second, Be gets a good look - it's JASON WILLETTE, 17. BACK TO BECCA — CONTINUOUS Becca leans forward, trying to get a better view of the b The light changes to green and the bus takes off. Becca, shaken, just watches it go. And then the car behin her starts honking, and Becca is snapped back to reality. She puts her foot on the gas.  23. EXT. ROADS OF LARCHMONT — DAY The school bus rolls through the manicured streets of the town. It stops at a corner to let a couple students off. And then the bus continues on. When it does, Becca's car rolls into frame, keeping a saf distance from the bus she’s trailing.
Becca watches the bus drive through a YELLOW LIGHT. Her e widen with alarm. Her foot on the accelerator. Her car moves through the intersection just as the light is turni RED.

The bus has stopped, and Becca pulls up a discreet distan behind it. This time a 14-YEAR-OLD GIRL gets off followed by...Jason, book-bag slung over his shoulder. The Girl wa off in one direction as the bus pulls away. Becca watches as Jason heads in the other direction and u the driveway of a nice house. He slips inside. Becca sits there for awhile. Then finally pulls away. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE’S LIVING ROOM — NIGHT Becca and Howie have settled onto the couch after dinner. Becca sits, lost in thought, holding an empty wine glass.
When did Rick ever beat me in squash?
Did he mention Debbie at all?
You can call her, you know. Get the reports directly.
I don’t wanna call her. She should call me. Howie heads into the kitchen and tosses the empty bottle the recycling bin.  24.
I would have been there for her if god forbid anything had ever happened to Robby or Em.
Howie stops at the fridge, and notices that Danny's paint are gone. Not sure what to make of it, he just stands the
I wouldn’t have vanished the way she did.
I wouldn't.
Howie?
Howie stands in the doorway, debating whether to mention paintings or not. He decides against it.
You know what I mean? Howie grabs a remote instead and clicks on the stereo. Al Green's "Simply Beautiful" plays quietly. Becca looks up, bemused.
Yeah. He moves onto the couch to massage her shoulders.
Howie.
Turn around. Come on, you need to relax. Howie starts to massage Becca’s back.
You're shoulders are all knotted up.
Yeah, well...  25.
Forget about Debbie, and whatever else is bothering you. Howie continues to massage her. Becca seems to warm up to it. He kisses her neck. She giggles a little.
Ohhh, I see what this is. Dimming the lights.
What.
You’re trying to seduce me. Plying me with liquor.
It worked in college.
That’s enough. Becca pushes him away playfully.
That's enough. (gets up off the couch)
Where are you going?
I'm feeling kinda antsy tonight. I’m sorry. It was a weird day--
Right. Howie clicks off the music, and lets out a grumpy sigh.
What, now you’re gonna pout?
Well it's been eight months.
(beat) But who's keeping track?  26.
Iam. I'm keeping track.
I'm just not ready yet, Howie. I'm sorry if you think that's abnormal--
I don't.
Then what's the problem?
We need to at least head in that direction, which might feel strange at first, but...
But you wanna have sex.
Well don't say it like that.
You’re trying to rope me into having sex!
I am not. I wasn't roping you into sex-—
Al Green isn't roping?
No.
Al Green?
I thought it was nice. That's all. I was trying to make things nice.

Well you can't. I'm sorry. But things aren't "nice" anymore. They're silent. Howie just stares at her.  27. LIVING ROOM — LATER THAT NIGHT Howie is seated with the lights off, watching a video of Danny on his phone. We see flashes of Danny on the little screen, spinning ar in what seems to be a tire swing. We hear a dog barking. HOWIE (on video) And, will you hold him for a second? Just hold him, just hold him like that. DANNY (on video) (laughing) Dad, quit it! BECCA (on video) (laughing) Quit it. The video is mostly a blur, with Danny’s laughing face co into focus for just a second as he swings on a tire swing

Yeah, pull him past you. All right, now. BECCA (on video) Cause Taz wants to go on the tire. HOWIE (on video) Hold on. Hold on. Let me see Mom and-- BECCA (on video) Okay, you ready? I’m gonna let you go. Ready? DANNY (on video) Yes. BECCA (on video) Here goes. There! Whoa! Keep your feet up. HOWIE (on video) Danny, look at me on the way back. BECCA (on video) Keep your feet up, Danny. Howie continues to watch the video.  28.

The hand reaches into frame and starts to place cutouts o the earlier seen portal openings on top of each other. The hand cuts out several more portal openings and adds t to the intersecting group. We pull back to reveal a large network of intersecting tunnels. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE'S EXERCISE ROOM — MORNING Becca is working out on the elliptical, listening to her Ipod, when Howie enters the room dressed for work. She looks over at him but doesn't stop her work-out.
Hey.
(after a pause) If you're not gonna go to Group, I think you should see someone. (pause - no response)
Uh-huh.
Any plans for the day?
You're looking at ‘em.
(pause) Well, I’1l see you tonight.
Yup. Becca never stops her workout. Howie heads upstairs.  29.
Becca is at the window, still winded and sweaty from her exercise, watching as Howie pulls out from his parking sp in front of the house. As soon as he drives off, she darts up the stairs.

Becca is rifling through her closet looking for an outfit She pulls out a couple business suits, wrapped in plastic and looks them over. She hasn't seen these in awhile. She holds one of the suits up to herself. She looks sligh pained. Is she really going to do this?

Showered and dressed, Becca applies a little makeup, then checks herself out in the mirror. She looks good. EXT. TRAIN STATION — A MOMENT LATER Becca, coffee and newspaper in hand, heads up to the trai platform just as the train pulls in. This all feels so familiar to her. EXT. MIDTOWN — MANHATTAN — DAY Becca walks towards us on a sidewalk. The streets are pac with people, and the sidewalks cramped with fruit stands kebab carts. Becca loves it all. Back in her element. A SHOT of the top of a sculptural Frank Gehry-like mirror building. We tilt down to find an ebullient Becca crossin the street and entering the building.
It's all glass and class in here. Becca approaches a RECEPTIONIST at the reception desk. She's all smiles and confidence.
Hi, I'm here to see Scott Bader in the Events Department.  The Receptionist searches her computer for the name.
I don't have a Bader listed.
Oh. Well that’s weird. 30. Her heart sinks. Not what she planned on. What to do now?
Kate Finn. What about Kate?
I have a Robert Finn in Dec. Arts? (Becca shakes her head) If you have an appointment, I can just call up there. Who are you?
(on the ropes a bit) Um...I’m just...I didn’t have an appointment actually. I'm just an old friend. I used to work here. She eyes her. She doesn’t remember her.
Becca? She turns to see a youngish guy in a suit, GARY, standing there with a Starbucks tray of several coffees. Former fr boy type. Becca doesn't recognize him at first, but then.
Gary?
Heeey. What are you doing here?
Um...I had some errands in the city, and thought I'd pop in and say hello. But apparently nobody works here anymore.
Oh yeah, Scott went over to Christie's back in March. The traitor.  31.
Well nice to see you’re still doing the coffee runs at least.

Oh, no, I don’t usually-- Um, I’m in Scott’s old job. Becca is clearly surprised, and a little confused. The lobby seems to be filled with people younger and bett dressed than Becca is. Being here suddenly feels like a b mistake. Becca fights the impulse to run for the exit.
Hey, how's the family?
You know what, Gary? I know how busy it gets up there, so I’m gonna let you get back to it.
(chuckles ) Yeah, that hasn't changed.
It was great to see you though.

Yeah, you too. And she takes off. In her haste, she nearly gets taken ou by the revolving door. She waits for the next opening, an makes her exit. Gary just stands with the coffees in the middle of the lo watching her go. That was weird.
Becca hurries down the street, shaken up, and eager to ge back home. Coming here was a terrible idea. EXT. SUBURBAN STREET — LARCHMONT - DAY
Becca drives with a purpose. She checks the time on her watch. If she hurries she can still make it.  32.

Becca is in her car, back in her spot, parked a safe dist from Jason’s house. Finally the school bus pulls up the hill. Becca slumps do in her seat so as not to be seen. The bus pulls over. Becca peeks up over the steering whee and watches as Jason gets off followed by the 14-year-old Girl. She walks off while Jason pauses on the sidewalk to adjust his backpack. The bus pulls away. But instead of heading to his house, Jason walks toward Becca.

Shit. Panicked, she grabs a baseball cap from the backseat and quickly puts it on. Jason, meanwhile, doesn't even notice her. He walks right past the car, and down the street. Have you heard from Debbie yet?
Nope.
That's too bad. But it can be worse the other way, you know. I remember when Arthur died-- (stops herself) Sorry. Nat bites her tongue and moves away. Becca feels badly.
You can say his name.
Can I? I don't know your rules, Becca. I don't wanna get scolded again.
You can talk about Arthur. I just don't like the comparisons.
(beat) Okay. A moment passes between them. Over the following, they continue to organize the toys...
(begrudgingly) So how is it worse?
You remember Maureen Bailey?
Yeah.  67.
I couldn't get rid of her after your brother passed away. She was always at the house.
Yeah, I remember that.
Yeah well, I never had a moment to myself. So finally in the middle of coffee one afternoon, I said, "Maureen, why are you always here?"
What'd she say?
She said, "I wanna be there, Nat, I wanna share in your grief." And so I said "Well it's not working. You plant your fat ass in that chair every frickin' day--"
You did not say that.

I did! "And you suck up all my coffee, and I don't see you leaving with any of this grief you're allegedly sharing with me. In fact the only thing you do take outta here are my cinnamon buns." (beat ) So I never saw her again obviously. Nat shrugs. She gets a genuine chuckle out of Becca.
I feel guilty now.
You do not.

(laughing) I do. (then) You’re right, I don’t. I don’t miss her at all.  68. EXT. BECCA’s HOME — DAY It is a bright sunny day. Becca’s home has an “open house sign in front of it. EXT. BECCA’S BACKYARD — SAME DAY Taz is back. Howie puts him on a runner in the back yard.
Becca pulls a warm pie out of the oven. It looks perfect. She moves it to the counter. Howie enters through the back door carrying Taz’s leash.
That takes care of Taz. (eyes the pie) Ah, the ol' apple pie trick, eh?
What?
For the Open House. Warm baked goods makes it feel homier. I thought you were doing it for the Open House.
Oh. No, I was just making a pie. Howie shrugs - wrong again. Becca tidies up.
So, you’re not gonna stay?
God, no. You shouldn't either. (off his chuckle) You shouldn't.
Come on, I'm not gonna bother anyone.  69. INT. FOYER — LATER THAT MORNING Howie is chatting with the slightly uptight middle-aged realtor woman, RHONDA. Becca's getting ready to go.
So we have the garbage cans in the back, the sign out front. I mowed the lawn. I thought we’d set the sign-in sheet here, and they could move into the living room.
That's fine.
My wife's gonna go hide out, but I'll stick around, if that's okay with you. Rhonda pauses slightly.
Sure. However you want to do it. Becca heads out.
Okay.

Bye. (back to Rhonda) I think that’s everything. EXT. PARK —- A LITTLE LATER Becca sits reading the parallel universe book on the same bench she sat with Jason. She didn't make plans with him, but half-hopes she might see him here. She puts down the book and looks around. There are parents minding their kids on the jungle gym. There's a couple sitting on the grass, sharing a newspape A group of guys play touch-football. Only Becca is by herself, and she feels it maybe harder than she ever has.  70. INT. HOWIE AND BECCA'S FOYER —- DAY Howie stands expectantly with a clipboard as a suburban couple (CRAIG and DONNA) with a four year old son, CADEN, come in from the living room with Rhonda.
Southwestern exposures. Sun all day.
The layout is exactly what we've been looking for.
(to Donna) And the light in here.
I know, it's beautiful.
Why don’t we take a look upstairs?
That's a great idea. I’11 show you. Follow me. He takes over, leading them upstairs. Rhonda is peeved.
Howie is leading the family past the doorway...
We can start in the master bedroom if you want to see-- But the wife stops and ducks into Danny’s room.
What’s in here?
Oh, that’s, uh-- The family enters the room. Howie follows them in. Rhonda appears in the doorway, concerned as to how this might go
This could be a good room for the little guy, obviously.  71.
How about that, buddy? You like this room? The boy makes a b-line for one of Danny's wind-up robots. Howie is immediately on edge.
Oo, careful with that.
That's not yours, honey. The boy reluctantly puts the toy down.
How old's your son? (off Howie's blank look) This is your son's room, I assume?
Uh, yeah. I mean...it was, but..-he died. Rhonda lowers her eyes. This is not the thing to say. The couple looks confused. This is suddenly very awkward.
Yeah, a car. Right out front.
Oh my god.
I’m so sorry.
Thank you.
This must be so difficult for you.

Yeah, it's pretty weird. I still forget he's not here sometimes. Like maybe he's just hiding under the bed or something, and he's gonna pop out. That’s what he used to do. (looks around) I still feel him here. This comes out weirder than Howie intends. The parents ar little creeped out. The little boy looks to the bed.  72.
(beat) Would you like to see the master bedroom? INT. IZZY'S BATHROOM —- MOMENTS LATER
Izzy, toothbrush in hand, is just finishing a phone call.
(on phone) Yeah, I'll be there. She hangs up her cell phone. Auggie pops his head in.
Who was that?

Becca. She wants to “hang out.” Auggie looks as confused as Izzy. She grabs one of her ne hand towels (from Becca's bathroom set) and wipes her mou The newly decorated bathroom looks fantastic. INT. UPSCALE NAIL SALON — DAY Izzy and Becca sit side by side getting pedicures. Becca flips through a magazine. The PEDICURISTS work in silence
This was a good idea.
Nice, right? Becca glances over at Izzy's belly.
You're starting to show so early.
I know. I feel like a big ole balloon. I swear, once this kid is born I’m going right to the gym.
While Mom watches the baby. Becca smiles and goes back to her magazine. Izzy can't qu tell if she's just been insulted.  73.
What does that mean? “While Mom watches the baby.”
While you're at the gym, Mom can watch the baby. She loves that.
No, Auggie can watch the baby. He works nights, so he'll be home.
Okay. Auggie, then. Becca passes her a magazine. Izzy is fighting to bite her tongue, but it’s a losing the battle.
If you’re gonna be mean to me, then I might as well stay home.
What’d I say?
You think I'm not cut out to be a good mother.
That is not what I think.
I know I'm not as organized as you are, or homey, or whatever--
Nobody's comparing us.
Really? Because that'd be a first.
Honestly, Izzy, I don't know what this is about.
It's about me being a capable person who can raise a child, and look after it and protect it. It’s not Izzy’s intention but this wounds Becca.  74.

I resent the feeling I get from you that I don't deserve the baby. Or that I'm not mature enough, or smart enough or something, to take care of it. I mean, my god, if Mom could do it, how hard could it be? Silence. They stare at each other. Then Becca goes back t her reading. INT. SUPERMARKET — DAY Becca and Izzy stroll along with the shopping cart. Muzak
This alright?
Yeah, it’s fine.
I’ve just gotta pick up a few things and then we can do lunch. Becca makes her way past walls of sugared kids’ cereals w colorful boxes. She rolls past, not daring to look at the
Becca notices a mother, LORI, at the end of the aisle. Sh is shopping with her little boy, SAMMY, in the cart. He's about five, and really not happy.
Please can I have some Fruit Roll- Ups?
No, Sammy, you know the answer.
Please? Can I have some, please?
Sammy. No. Lori very deliberately turns her back on the boy and scan the shelf in front of her, ignoring him entirely, which o angers him more.
I want the Fruit Roll-ups.
Not happening.
Please, I’1ll be good.
Stop it.
Please?
No.
I promise.

No, I’m not gonna get ‘em. Becca tries to not pay attention, but it gets under The boy's whines turn into wails, and still the mom nothing. It goes on for several beats, until Becca take it anymore. She is suddenly striding down the toward them. Surprised, Izzy hurries after her... But it's too late, Becca is already talking to Lori.
You know what? It's only three bucks, why don't you just get him the roll-ups? The boy stops whining. He and Izzy look to Lori to response. The woman’s eyes narrow.
Not that it's any of your business, but we don't allow candy in our house, and my son knows that.
Come on, it’s just fruit. Why don’t you give him a treat? 75. her skin. does can’t aisle see her  76.
Are you a mom? The question hangs there. Izzy lowers her eyes. Becca is obviously caught off-guard. She struggles to respond.

Yeah, I didn’t think so. (moves her cart) Excuse me... Becca suddenly reaches up and smacks her across the face. Hard. The woman stares at her, shocked. Becca and Izzy lo equally shocked. Did that really just happen? The boy looks as if he’s been hit too.
Go to the car, Becca. She doesn't move. Izzy hisses through gritted teeth...
I said go to the car. Becca, slightly dazed, steps away from them. Everything around her swirls a bit as she breaks into a run and dash for the exit.
(explains to Lori) She just lost her son eight months ago and she’s--
I don’t care. INT. BECCA'S CAR — PARKING LOT - MOMENTS LATER
Becca and Izzy sit in the car, still shaken.
Howie is looking over the sign-in sheet. Taz is barking o in the yard. Becca and Izzy come in with the grocery bags Becca unpacks the groceries over the following...  77.
So? Fun day out? Becca tosses Izzy a warning glance.
How'd it go here?
Not so good. We need to clean out that room.
(pause) Okay.
Maybe make it into a guest room or something. (to Izzy) Don't get any ideas.

Ha-ha. Then Izzy's smiles disappears. She looks scared. Becca notices and turns around - what's wrong? Howie turns too. And then we see... Jason is standing in the doorway of the kitchen. He's somehow walked in unnoticed.
Jesus...
Hello. Hi...um...The door was wide open so... (no response) And I knocked, but... They all stand there, still taken aback by the moment. Ta is still barking.
Taz! Shut up! Taz stops barking. They all stare at Jason.  78.
I saw the sign outside...the Open House sign, so I thought it’d be okay to--
You looking to buy a house?
Howie--
No.
(turns to Becca) I just came to give you this. Jason holds out the "Rabbit Hole" comic book to Becca.
I said I'd let you read it when it was done, so... Becca stands motionless. There's no way out of this. She finally reaches out and takes the book.
Thank you. Howie looks from Becca to the boy, completely dumbstruck. Izzy is wide-eyed with curiosity. Becca can't even look a Howie. Jason starts to realize what he's done.
What...what is this?
We...bumped into each other, in the library, and we decided to meet.
You decided to meet.
Yeah. A couple times. Howie shakes his head. This is getting weirder and weirde
I'm sorry. I didn't realize--  79.
Did you meet here?
No, we met in the park.
You met in the park a couple times.
Yeah. Howie's breathing becomes shallow. He's trying hard to ke his anger under control. He advances on Jason a little bi
So my wife agrees to meet you ina public place, and you...what? Apologize?
I guess.
Okay, you apologize, and then what?
Alright, Howie, that's enough.
(xe: book) What is that?
It’s a comic book.
It’s a comic book. A comic book. Izzy looks to her sister like, what the hell?
Did she tell you to bring it here?
Howie--
No, she didn't.  80.
No, she didn't. Because this is our house. And just because there's a sign out front doesn't mean you can pop in.
Howie, all right.
No it’s not alright. You don't just walk into someone's home like that. You should show a little fucking respect. Jason looks to Becca, then makes a quick exit. They're all silent for a couple beats.
(quietly) You're an asshole. She goes out after Jason. Howie watches her go. Izzy puts groceries away.
(whispers to himself) I’m an asshole.

location: SIDEWALKS AROUND HOWIE AND BECCA'S HOUSE

text: Howie, still rattled, is walking Taz on a leash. The big, dumb dog is essentially pulling him down the block.

Easy... He tugs on the leash, but Taz pays no mind. The dog continues to pant and pull, excited to be out of the yard Again, Howie snaps the leash hard, but it hardly does anything. Howie is getting pissed.
Taz, stop it. Taz suddenly sees/hears some small animal in the hedged-i property next to the sidewalk. He leaps towards the hedge barking ferociously.  81.
Taz. Taz, stop it! Howie snaps the leash back way too hard, and Taz lets out pained YELP! The dog retreats from the hedges, and cowers Howie immediately feels horribly, and runs to him.

Oh, buddy... He buries his face in the dog's fur. He feels to make sur he's okay. Howie rubs his neck and pats his fur. Taz look up tentative, and licks Howie's hand. The dog's fine. But Howie feels like a complete and utter heel. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE'S KITCHEN — EVENING
Becca is rolling out dough for a pie crust. Howie appears the doorway. He stands and watches for a moment.
Why didn’t you tell me? She stops and looks up at him.

(simply) For the same reason you don’t tell me why you come home reeking of pot. Howie takes this in. Then retreats quietly from the doorw Becca goes back to rolling her pie crust. INT. GARAGE — DAY Becca and Nat carry the milk crates of Danny's stuff down the basement, and put them in the corner with a few other things Becca has put aside. Becca stands there, taking it in. Danny's been reduced to small corner of stuff in the basement. She lets out a breath, then turns to her mother.
Does it ever go away?
What.  82.
This feeling. They lock eyes. Nat can see she actually wants an answer. Maybe for the first time ever.
No. I don't think it does. Not for me it hasn't. And that's goin' on eleven years. (beat) It changes though.
How?

I don't know. The weight of it, I guess. At some point it becomes bearable. It turns into something you can crawl out from under, and carry around - like a brick in your pocket. And you forget it every once in a while, but then you reach in for whatever reason and there it is: "Oh right. That." Which can be awful. But not all the time. Sometimes it's kinda... Not that you like it exactly, but it's what you have instead of your son, so you don't wanna let go of it either. So you carry it around. And it doesn't go away, which is...
What.
Fine...actually. They're silent for a couple beats. Becca nods a little. N turns and heads up the basement steps.

They're both in bed reading. Becca is engrossed in Jason' comic book. Howie glances over, a bit annoyed by it. We see a panel - the boy in the story is running from an of armor-clad knights.  83. He passes through a portal, and in the next panel he's falling through another rabbit hole. He lands on a suburb block. The thought-bubble over the boy's head reads, "There's my house! I'm back home!" We follow Becca’s eye across the panels. We see the boy a the front door of the house, and the parents staring down him confused. The bubble over the boy’s head reads, “It’s me! Your son!” And the mother’s bubble reads, “But we don have a son.” The next panel: a close-up of the boy’s devastated face. in the next panel, he asks them, “Would you like one?” Becca lets out a little gasp when she sees the picture. Howie looks over, intrigued. But she doesn’t explain.
Gabby walks to answer the phone.
Hello? INT. HOWIE'S OFFICE —- MANHATTAN - INTERCUT PHONE CALL
Hey, it's Howie. Howie Corbett. From Group? Gabby is obviously taken aback.

Hi, Howie. EXT. YARD — LATE AFTERNOON Taz is barking and jumping as Howie makes his way to the house. Howie places the food down, and Taz attacks it. Howie turns back to the house, and sees Becca working in garden. She's looking at him strangely.
Hey.
Hi. You're going to group tonight, right?  84.
(tries to sound off-hand) Yeah. You didn't want to come, did you?
No. Howie tries to not look relieved. Becca looks a little guilty, as if she might have a secret as well.
I'm just gonna hop in the shower.
Okay. He gives a little wave, and heads in. Becca watches him g

location: BECCA AND HOWIE'S FRONT OF HOUSE

text: Howie, freshly showered and changed, heads for his car. O guilty look over his shoulder, and he gets in.
Becca watches from behind a curtain as Howie's car pulls away. As soon as it does, she grabs the "Rabbit Hole" com book and her car keys, and heads for the kitchen.

Now Becca pulls out of the driveway, and drives off in th opposite direction. As they drive down various suburban roads, we intercut between the two cars. Becca and Howie are both nervous, a eager to get where they're going. INT. BECCA’S CAR — DUSK Becca places the comic book up on the dashboard. INT. HOWIE'S CAR — DUSK Howie checks his teeth in the rearview mirror.  85. INT. BECCA'S CAR — INTERCUT Becca is on her cell phone. We hear Jason’s voice on the outgoing message. Becca hangs up before it’s finished.

Howie finally reaches his destination. It's a beautiful house on a nice block. He slows to a stop at the curb. He puts the car into park. He looks up at the house, and takes a deep breath. He's terrified. He doesn't move. He just sits in his car.

Finally, he can't bear it anymore. He opens the car door, and gets out. He smooths his shirt, and heads up the walk way toward Gabby's front door. It's just a few yards, but the walk may as well be a hundred miles. The door opens, and Gabby steps outside. She looks pretty
Did you find the house okay? Howie doesn't respond. He doesn't even move.
Howie? Is he going to go through with this?

She pulls up Jason's block, and can't help smiling. She's grown to enjoy these encounters with him. But as she gets closer, her smile fades. She's really not expecting to see the scene in front of her.

Becca stops the car a safe distance away, unnoticed by anyone. There's a limo parked at the bottom of the drivew Becca watches as Jason, in a tuxedo, very self-consciousl pins a corsage to a SKINNY GIRL in a prom dress.  86. JASON'S MOTHER, giddy with pride, takes picture after picture. JASON'S BUDDY and his BUDDY'S DATE heckle them f inside the car. When it's time to go, Jason and his date, move to squeeze the back seat. Lots of good-natured shoving, and big dres flipping up, and laughing. Jason's mother, laughing herself, captures it all on film INT. BECCA'’S CAR — CONTINUOUS It's a relatively benign scene, but Becca watches it as someone might watch a car-wreck - stunned, confused, a li disbelieving... The limo doors close, and as it's about to drive off... ...something huge and uncontrollable opens up inside of Becca, and she begins to cry. A lot. She clutches the steering wheel and pretty much loses it.

Jason, at the wheel of his car, terror in his eyes, turns see Becca standing outside of her house, trembling, not comprehending at all what she sees. They lock eyes. Though Becca has just seen the body of Danny, we never do We only see Becca and Jason in this moment. And then... INT. LIMO — SIMULTANEOUS (SLO-MO Still laughing, Jason turns for just a moment and sees Becca's car as they roll by. Becca is hysterical but sile behind the glass of her windows. Jason's smile disappears
Jason watches as Becca and her car disappear behind him, he continues on to his prom.

head_text.subj: BACK TO HOWIE OUTSIDE GABBY'S HOUSE

text: Howie is still standing there. Gabby is waiting. She trie to smile. Howie takes a step back.  87.

(barely a whisper) I'm sorry. Howie turns, and heads for the car. He gets back in. Gabb watches as he starts the car and pulls away. When he's gone, her shoulders drop in defeat. She slips inside, and gently closes the door behind her. INT. HOWIE'S CAR — SPEEDING HOME - MOMENTS LATER

Howie is suddenly in a big hurry to get home. He flies through the suburban back roads, determined, and terrifie the very big mistake he very nearly made. EXT. HOWIE AND BECCA’S FRONT OF HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER

Howie gets out of the car, and yanks the back door open. grabs the booster from the back seat, and tosses it in th bags of garbage that have been put on the curb for pick-u He closes the car door, and heads into the house.
Howie tosses his keys by the door, and peeks into the liv room, but there's no one here.
No sign of Becca. He peers out the kitchen window into th backyard. Taz is asleep in the dog house. He moves to the basement door, and listens. Nothing. He calls down the stairs.
Becca? Still, nothing. This is odd. Where did she go?
He runs upstairs, a bit of panic creeping in now.
Becca...?  88.

He ducks his head in. No one there. INT. DANNY'S ROOM —- CONTINUOUS Howie clicks on the light. Of course there's no one here either. He looks around the room. But there's nothing. Other than the stripped bed, the room is completely empty And slowly, we see Howie’s determination drain out of his body. He’s too late. Becca isn’t here. And he’s convinced she’s actually left him. Spent, Howie sits on the bed, staring off into space. The he quietly takes off his shoes, and lies back on the bed. BACK TO BECCA IN HER CAR - STILL ACROSS FROM JASON’S HOUS The prom car is gone. Becca is alone now. The street is empty again. She finally lets go of the steering wheel. Her crying is pretty much over. But she doesn't start the car. She just sits there.
Becca is asleep in her car - pretty much where we left he There a little tap-tap-tap at her window. She wakes up, disoriented, and sees Jason outside, still in his tuxedo.
Jesus.
Sorry.
What time is it?
Almost five?

And you're just getting home?  89. EXT. PARK — MINUTES LATER They're back on their bench. The sun is creeping over the fields of the park. They've been sitting here for awhile without saying anything.
So how was it?
It was okay.
Well you look nice.
Thank you.
Was that your girlfriend?
Just a friend.
She's pretty. Jason looks to "Rabbit Hole" which sits on the bench betw them. Becca smiles, and picks up the comic book.
Well, I liked this so much. It’s beautiful.
Thanks.
It reminded me of Orpheus and Eurydice. Do you know that myth?
Not really.
Eurydice dies, and Orpheus misses her so much, that he travels to Hades to retrieve her, but in the end it doesn't work out.  90.
I should read it. Becca flips through the book. Jason undoes his bow-tie.
So, is the scientist your dad? (off his blank look) The scientist the boy is looking for, is that your dad?
(beat) No.
I mean, is it based on him?
No. My dad was an English teacher.
Oh. Okay. I was curious about that part.
It's just a story.
No, I know. I was just...
Reading into it?
Yeah. They sit there. A jogger runs by in silence.
Do you think they're real?
Parallel universes?
I think it’s basic science. If space is infinite, then everything is possible.  91. She smiles a little. This was the answer she was hoping f
So somewhere out there, there's a version of me -- what? -- making pancakes?
Sure.
Or at a water park.
Wherever, yeah. Both. Laws of probability. There are tons of you's out there, and tons of me's.
So this is just the sad version of us.
(beat) I guess.
But there are other versions where everything goes our way.
Assuming you believe in science.

(beat) Well that's a nice thought. That somewhere out there I'm having a good time. Jason smiles. They look out over the fields, and the sun peeking through the trees. INT. DANNY'S ROOM — MORNING Howie fell asleep on Danny's bed last night. He wakes up, squinting at the sun coming in from the windows. We hear the clink of mugs being taken from a cabinet, and coffee being made. Morning sounds.  92. It's so strikingly normal that Howie wonders for a moment he isn’t imagining it. And when he realizes he isn’t, a w of relief washes over him. INT. KITCHEN — MOMENTS LATER Becca is at the table, drinking her coffee, nibbling on a piece of pastry. Howie comes in, still sleepy, and takes in the scene. He gets a mug, and pours himself some coffee. Howie gets a plate, and cuts himself a piece. Then moves the table. They drink their coffee. After a while...
I thought maybe you had left. She sees the fear in his eyes, and she feels badly for hi
No. I didn't leave. Howie hides his relief by reaching for the morning paper, leafing through its contents.
So I was thinking we should invite Rick and Debbie over for a cookout. Howie looks up at her, totally perplexed.
She's never gonna call. She thinks I hate her. I might as well just let her off the hook.
So a cookout then.
It'll be good to see the kids. We should get something for Emily though. We missed her birthday. She turned four last week.
Right. Okay. Howie stares into his coffee mug.  93.
Danny's is coming up.
I know.
That's gonna be a tough one.
Yeah. Howie looks up at her.
So the kid... Jason. Did you tell him we didn't blame him?
We don’t blame him.
No, I know, but did you let him know that?
I guess so.
(beat) That's good.
Look, Howie, if you want talk with him.
I don't.
Okay. They pick at the Danish.
It's so quiet.  94.
That's because I slipped Taz a couple Ambien.
(smiles) You're funny.
You think I'm joking. A nice moment between them. It’s been awhile since they’v had one. Becca faces him - down to business now.
So what are we gonna do?
About what?
I don't know, pick something.
(thinks it over) Well...We could go to Village Toys tomorrow and pick up Candy Land for Emily. That's probably something she'd like.
Okay, Candy Land. That's a start. Then what?
Then we wrap it.
Uh-huh.
And then we have the cookout... Howie's voice continues over the following scenes...  95.

A bright day. Howie is at the grill. Nat is blabbing away to him. Becca is chatting with her neighbors (Peg and Pet Rick and Debbie come through the back gate with EMILY, 4 ROBBIE, 7. Becca gets up and welcomes them.

And they'll come over, and we'll have a couple other people so it's not too awkward for anyone. Debbie is still rather sheepish and apologetic when greet Becca. The kids make a b-line for Taz, who's tied up in t doghouse, and happy to see them.

And to make them feel comfortable we'll ask a bunch of questions about what the kids have been up to, and we'll pretend that we're really interested. Howie's voice continues over several more shots from the Izzy, looking especially pregnant, shows up with Auggie. She's brought some kind of pie. Becca seems both shocked impressed by it. Despite the iconic suburban cookout, this should feel mor winsome than happy. The unresolved issues linger.

And then we'll wait for someone to bring up Danny while the kids are playing. And maybe that'll go on for a little while. And as he describes, we see them all sitting around havin some adult conversation as the sun goes down. SAME — DUSK Everyone's gone. Howie and Becca are sitting next to each other in separate chairs looking out at the fading light the water. They are both lost in thought. All around them is the wreckage of the cookout.  96.
And after that they'll go home. Becca glances over at Taz, who is quiet and exhausted.
And then what?
(beat) I don't know. Something though. We'll figure it out.
Will we?

I think so. I think we will. Becca looks to Howie. They both look a bit scared. She reaches over and takes his hand...for the first time very long time. It's a simple gesture - not of resolution - but of possibility. Howie holds on tight. And we... FADE OUT.
